content.description:
The White Rose is now the best (only) warm up on the White Wall. Like its black counterpart, The White Rose is fun climbing on great rock. Expect some smaller gear and a short bouldery crux in a way that only a rose could grow on the White Wall. 

  Start up towards a short roof using the puzzle piece block on Billy the Kid to Forks Stem into a dihedral (5.8+) climb much easier but quality terrain to a stance.
content.protection: Single Set from #000 C3-#.5 C4   Double of #.75 C4 may be useful   A set of small nuts will help protect the 5.8+ move getting into the dihedral.   Runners
content.location: The short dihedral on the left side of the Zebra Face. Shares the same first piece as Billy the Kid.

climbs.name: The White Narwhal
climbs.fa: J.Snyder, A.Maryn, J.Hereford, M.Yamamoto, K.Mertz, CuzCo.org

content.description:
Part mythical/magical bouldering beast; Part White Wall tradtastics. The White Narwhal is the unicorn of The Forks, and worth chasing. Be like H.M. and get "tormented by an itch for things remote."   

  Several sections of the climb are unprotected, the top runout being the most serious. Caution riding a beast with a magical horn.
content.protection: Micro Cams   Slider Nuts   Micro Nuts   Couple of finger sized Cams.     Runners   Rope
content.location: The White Narwhal climbs the largest red and white streaked prow just left of New Kid on the Block and "that 5.11+". Look for steep seam, sea(able) from The Prow.

content.description: Exquisite movement on Perfect Stone. 5 Stars anywhere! Getting to the first bolt proves a battle of its own with a bold clip-point at fifteen feet off the deck; an alpine draw in its extended position is intended for the first bolt. Dance right across insecure smears to reach a triad of large angled edges just below the second bolt. Clip it, then drop back into the no hands rest at the shared holds of Tiger Bomb and The Egg Timer, the last rest before the top. Pull deep onto a series of small crimps to gain a crisp gash hidden just out of sight at the left (the first crux). Clip into the final bolt before being presented with the true grit of the Tiger: crush down on small hands to gain a high in-cut right foot, drive your left hand to your waist, FIGHT GRAVITY to a jug, and achieve the start of the gear section of the climb. Full value eliminate-style bouldering and endurance climbing guide you to the top.
content.protection: In this order:   3 draws   #.5, #.4, Red #1 C3   It is highly recommended to pre-clip the three bolts that protect this route.
content.location: Near the middle of the White Wall, directly left of The Egg Timer, up the blank, yellow and orange striped face with a right trending diagonal crack leading to the summit.

content.description: With your first gear placement being a ball nut 15+ feet  off the deck, and the following three pieces being slider nuts as well, the mental battle with feeling safe evokes tenuous movement. Succeed through the opening sequence of exaggerated highstep-stemming before formatting your personal barn door solution. Gun it to a pair of straight-edge jugs at the obvious #2 Cam slot, recharge your battery before making a tough nut placement, then execute a few reachy moves on small but positive slots, surmounting the large ledge via a lava-esque basalt topout.
content.protection: In this order:   Red #2 Ball Nut (15 ft. up),    Red #2 Ball Nut,   Blue #1 Ball Nut,    Red #2 Ball Nut (Blind Placement),   Red C3 #1, Gold #2 Camalot,    Small #3 (blue) wire stopper,    Small #6 (green) wire stopper
content.location: A thin seam at the far left side of the White Wall with a subtle S-Curve, just left of Meat Puppet.

content.description: Climb the flaring offwidth to a sit down at the base of White Wall "power spot." Execute a couple finger crack moves over highly textured terrain before beginning an exciting sequence of bouldery moves protected by bolts.
content.protection: 4 bolts   Small Nuts   #00 C3
content.location: Right of Hocus Focus and left of Tatanka Blanca; left most route of the White Wall "Power Spot."

content.description:
Steep and broken face moves to the sweet corner. Very cool tips to second digit leaning layback locks to a steepening good finger section to the rim. 

  Again, good rock and good movements...
content.protection: (2)0-2 TCU's, (3)3 TCU, med/sm wired nuts

content.description: Excellent and dynamic climbing up face/seams with small corners to a two-finger pocket, and the cranky crux...  Big move! Climb steep face to top.
content.protection: Most will want to throw a TR on this thing, but it has seen several bold leads.
content.location: Somewhere down there inbetween Forks Flyer and Perfect beast.

content.description:
Named because it was a Perfect Beast to test out new Wired Bliss camming prototypes back in the mid 80â€™s.

 Climb the left trending crack through funky jams and a long reach to a distant finger jam. After the crux there are two variations, the left of which is far better. Climb up and left in the crack to the top and a rap anchor.
content.protection: Doubles .3- .75, #1 and #2, wires.
content.location: Middle right side.

content.description: There is a little bit of everything on this route from delicate face climbing to powerful pulling. Excellent rock with a thin seam roof leads to a slab, below twin cracks in a corner. Previously only Top Roped, this classic takes bits of gear the whole way.
content.protection: Small stuff, and doubles of .3-.5.
content.location: At the middle of the White Wall, the trail cuts a path between the crag wall and a large fallen pillar. This marks the base of Pandora's Box; streaked black rock with a small looming roof halfway up. Climber's right of Prudence, and just downhill from Eggtimer.

content.description: A nice moderate(for the White Wall) line that serves up pretty casual, fun climbing. Lots of face holds and rests make this quite a bit different from the sustained Forks jam fests that you came for. Climb a slab to a hollow block in the initial bulge. Follow the leaning ladder up and right, Â crank a few finger locks. A boulder problem out right gets you under the improbable looking roof. Stuff in a variety of gear and float crux sport moves up into the ball pit. Tip toe to the top a few body lengths without gear.
content.protection: A double set of TCU's from #0 to #3 Metolius and singles to BD #1 will sew it up nicely. Small to med. nuts also very helpful. Runners for most pieces.
content.location: On the White Wall, left of Forks Flyer, start on the left end of the red soil. Look for a bulge 20 feet up and a finger crack by the arÃªte. Exit the top roof to the right. The top has no gear, but a stout Pine tree about 60 back from the top offers the best anchor...When you are on top, its below the northern end of the grassy clearing.

content.description:
A route that came to be under the full moon of the Summer Soltice, Moonrise Kingdom is a powerful love story about thin cracks, thinner protection, and fierce boulder problems that, for once, may favor the short.   

  Start Moonrise Kingdom on unprotectable terrain to a stance for your first piece 18ft off the ground (V3+ R). After finding tiny pro move under the shield. Place your fragile tips just so and then try to pull them off. After some slab campusing move into the steep thin boulder problem to the finish stance on a ledge.
content.protection: #000 C3- #2 C4 1-2x   Small nuts   Runners
content.location: Found on the right side of the Zebra Face to the right of a large outcove. Look for thin seam on a shield.

content.description:
More fingers and stemming?? Can we get some variety, please?? 

  Yet another one of the cool "white" panels on the wall... 

  Face climb broken rock to a thin finger splitter, straight in offset. Continue with good stemming along the continuous sized crack to a funky top out.
content.protection: #2 Camalot, (2)1, (2)2 TCU's, (1) 0-3 TCU's, .5, .75 Camalots

content.description:
"One sees clearly only with the heart. What is essential is invisible to the eye." -The Fox (Antoine de Saint-ExupÃ©ry) 

  The Little Prince is a nice line that climbs on an arete on the far right side of the Zebra Face. A line that looks improbable and almost impossible from the ground opens itself up with just enough face holds and tricky beta to make an exceptional "moderate". Potentially a harder onsight, be ready for small gear and some classic basalt face climbing. 5.11++? 

  Start on easy terrain to a thin crack and a stance. Bust a move and gain the horizonal seam. Traverse right and under the crux boulder section. Plunge through and to a stance under a small roof. Traverse right out onto the final headwall on the arete. Blocky  holds to a topout.
content.protection: Slider nuts   #000 C3- #2 C4   Nuts?   Runners
content.location: Right side of the Zebra Face, look for the unlikely seam next to an arete.

content.description: Long moves on cobble-like edges reach a rest several meters up at your first well earned placement; a glove-fit offset yellow stopper. Execute an easy mantle to gain an effortless no hands rest on the large ramping ledge. Oppose the offset seam and establish your left foot on a greasy yet positive imperfection far on the left face. Press where you can with the right hand and take advantage of the mediocre left hand crimp to assist upward movement. A high right foot smear on B-B sized protrusions proved the only solution to an otherwise impossible crux. Levitate into the featureless flare and will yourself into lying back off to the right of the seam. Balance through powerful open handed laybacks, walk high on slick foot smears, and sink a strenuous kneebar at the Green C3 placement. Grasp the only jug on the route before performing the final hard moves: bumping the right hand up gaston crimps and pressing into the hand crack below the roof. Weasel out of the roof onto an arete, ascending good holds and and a small scramble to a big ledge with a Juniper.
content.protection: Yellow #7 offset nut   Purple #.00 C3   Blue #3 nut   Blue #1 Lowe Ball   Quickdraw   #3 Camalot   Red #2 Lowe Ball   Green #0 C3   A second Blue #3 nut (optional)   #2 Camalot   #.2 (optional)
content.location: Right of 'The Troll" at the far left side of the White Wall is an obtuse, black streaked left facing corner beneath a small roof system.

content.description:
Hocus Focus climbs the center face of the Zebra. Great movement and a wild crux will make you Hocus Focus.  

  Not dangerous but very specific gear at the start makes for a heads up onsight or a tumble.
content.protection: #00 C3- #1 C4   Nuts   Runners
content.location: Right side of Zebra Face, climbs through varied terrain and arete.

content.description: Not your typical .12 at the Forks and one of the harder off widths in NAZ. Climb the crack which simply widens the whole way and gets steeper as well. The burly crux is near the end.
content.protection: Standard and wide
content.location: Middle left side of White Wall.

content.description: Perhaps the best stemming route at Paradise Forks.Very powerful for the arms and legs.Used to be a bold lead on Lowe Balls. C3's make the gear great. One of the all time Fork's sand bags. Originally rated 5.12-.
content.protection: Many 00 and 000- C3 Camalots.
content.location: Right of Prudence and left of Popeye.

content.description: Thought provoking and powerful moves through a corner on great rock, I originally stayed in the corner and thought it was quit a bit harder than the given grade, climbing to the right of the corner may or may not make it easier according to the second ascent, let me know what you think. Envisioned, cleaned and equipped by Tony SchwartzÂ
content.protection: An assortment of Ball Nuts and small to medium wires + a few .3s.
content.location: Corner between Popeye and Thin Lizzy. 2 bolt anchor.Â

content.description: A chest height mantle starts this short but engaging voyage through sparse imperfections: a stem corner with face holds out left leads to tight finger pods and an 'almost TOO good' hand jam. A couple more moves on perfect fingers and big jugs take you to the rim. Short, but super sweet.
content.protection: Ball Nuts   Small to Medium Stoppers   Green C3's   #.3 (x2)   #.4 (x2)
content.location: Bronzed left facing corner at the far right side of the White Wall.

content.description:
Billy the Kid is a short little rowdy route on the left side of the Zebra Face. A wild tradyno crux sequence will force you to be quick on the draw. 

  Start up towards the puzzle block and through broken face climbing into a flare pod. Get creative and move through some mantels into easy terrain to a stance.  

  Not dangerous but specific gear and climbing above said gear required. No one has taken "the whip" yet...
content.protection: Single #00 C3-#1 C4   Double #.75 C4 will protect the start and the crux   Runners   Nuts?
content.location: Left side of Zebra Face, shares the same first piece as The White Rose. Moves straight up through varied terrain.

content.description: While we find it hard to believe that this is a FA we will claim it til someone states otherwise and if it's an old route, well it's a gem that deserves to be climbed!  Anyhow start as for Perfect Beast and traverse right under the roof, crossing the choss into a thin seam.  Small gear and great moves take you up to a great stance below the crux tips section... Plug some tiny gear and enter hero mode up to a bomber lock and then ledge system.  Head up and right to belay for White Rose.   Thin climbing that's easier, (not easy), than it looks.
content.protection: Doubles from tiny to .75 Camalot.
content.location: Right of Perfect Beast

content.description: Another Day in Paradise consists of multiple cruxes, solid gear, awesome holds and just a bit of spice! Boulder out of Sedona up big ledges to gain the actual rock. Solid gear is had once at the stance below the roof. Puzzle your way up to the roof and some jams. Swing right and giggle up heroic section of thin hands. As the crack pinches down, fussy but good gear will see you into the cramped stance below the final roof. A blind nut can protect the final section, but only if you get it right! Engineer your way up positive choss through the 'ball pit' to the top.
content.protection: A lot of the pitch wanted to eat small nuts, while cams of the same size never quite sat right.   I used 2X #3-6 BD Stoppers, 1X#8,9 BD Stopper. 1X TCU's and cams from BD#00-#2 with 2X BD .3's. On top, grab a rap line and tie it off of a pine 60 feet back from the edge for a solid anchor. Bring plenty of runners as the crack wanders a lot.
content.location: This slice of paradise sits on the left edge of the White Wall, about 25 feet left of Forks Flyer in the middle of the red soil.  Climb around the left side of a horizontal roof 20 feet up.

content.description: The White Wall (or The White Wine Wall) is the furthest established cliff down the canyon on the north side and is very easily seen from atop the Prow. The lines are a lot less traveled than the rest of the Forks and may require a little more time to rig because of the slopey top. Despite the choss on top the climbing here is good with hard face/seams and beautiful cracks set at eye catching angles.Â
